choices.text: Ebstein's anomaly
Transposition of great arteries (TGA)
Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC)

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician's office by his parents, who report that he has been having episodes of cyanosis, especially during feeding and crying. The baby was born at full term without any complications during the pregnancy or delivery. On physical examination, the pediatrician notices that the infant has clubbing of his fingers and toes and a harsh systolic murmur heard best at the upper left sternal border.  His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Option C:

 

The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) TOF includes four defects: right ventricular hypertrophy, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and pulmonary stenosis. The classic chest X-ray finding in TOF is a "boot-shaped" heart, due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and a concave pulmonary artery segment caused by pulmonary stenosis. The clinical presentation of cyanotic spells and a systolic murmur align with this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ebstein's Anomaly: Ebstein's anomaly is associated with tricuspid regurgitation and right heart enlargement but does not typically present with a boot-shaped heart on a chest radiograph.

 

Option B. Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA): TGA is a condition where the main arteries (pulmonary artery and aorta) are switched in position (transposed). This leads to cyanosis and heart failure in newborns but does not cause a boot-shaped heart on chest radiograph. It's often diagnosed shortly after birth due to severe cyanosis.

 

Option D. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Return (TAPVC): TAPVC is a condition where all four pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium but instead connect to a systemic vein or the right atrium. It typically presents with cyanosis and signs of heart failure in infancy but not with a boot-shaped heart on radiography.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) the clinical features of cyanotic episodes, clubbing, and systolic murmur along with the chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are seen.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 146.

choices.text: A ruptured gastric ulcer
A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm
Acute appendicitis
An abscess in the psoas muscle

questions.text: A 75-year-old male patient came to ER with the complaint of severe abdominal pain. CTA was performed which is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm

 

Option B:

 

The CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta. This is a result of extra luminal contrast being expelled from a ruptured aortic aneurysm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A ruptured gastric ulcer: A ruptured gastric ulcer typically presents with sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that may radiate to the back. On imaging, especially CT, we might see evidence of perforation with free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum). This finding is not consistent with the provided CTA image.

 

Option C. Acute appendicitis: Patients with acute appendicitis typically present with abdominal pain that begins around the navel and later localizes to the lower right abdomen, accompanied by fever and leukocytosis. A CTA would show an enlarged, inflamed appendix, potentially with an appendicolith (a calcified deposit), but no contrast extravasation outside the aorta as seen in the provided image.

 

Option D. An abscess in the psoas muscle: A psoas abscess would typically present with flank pain, fever, and a palpable mass, or difficulty with movements that involve the psoas muscle. On CTA, an abscess may appear as a well-defined fluid collection with possible enhancement after contrast administration. Again, this does not match the findings in the CTA image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis is B - A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The provided CTA shows a soft tissue density with contrast visible outside of the left side of the abdominal aorta, indicative of extraluminal contrast from a ruptured aortic aneurysm. This is an urgent surgical emergency requiring immediate attention.

 

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 200.

choices.text: SVC
IVC
Right atrium
Right ventricle

questions.text: On a chest x-ray, which of the following structures does not make up the right cardiac border?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Right ventricle

 

Explanation:

 

Borders of Right heart

 

SVC – constitutes the uppermost portion of the right heart border (Option A)

 

Right atrium – constitutes the majority of the right heart border (Option C)

 

IVC – constitutes a minor portion of the right heart border (Option B)

 

Right ventricle contributes to the base or inferior boundary and not to the right heart border.

 

 

Important:

 

Due to aortic unfolding in the aged population or in aortic stenosis, ascending aorta rarely contributes to the formation of the right heart border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right ventricle contributes to the base or inferior boundary of the heart on a chest x-ray and does not make up the right heart border, which is instead formed by the SVC, IVC, and predominantly the right atrium.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 36.

choices.text: Chest x-ray
Electrocardiogram
Echocardiogram
Computed tomography angiography

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents to their primary care physician with a complaint of dysphagia. He reports that he experiences a sensation of food getting stuck in his throat when he eats. He also reports some mild chest discomfort with exertion. The patient has a history of Down syndrome and congenital heart disease. Which imaging modality is typically used to diagnose dysphagia lusoria?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Computed tomography angiography

 

Option D:

 

Computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirms the diagnosis of an aberrant right subclavian artery that is compressing the esophagus, leading to his dysphagia, known as dysphagia lusoria.

 

Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) CTA is a specialized radiographic technique that combines CT scanning with angiography to visualize blood vessels. A CTA of the chest would be the imaging modality of choice to confirm the diagnosis of an aberrant right subclavian artery compressing the esophagus, resulting in dysphagia lusoria. This technique provides detailed images of the blood vessels and surrounding structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: A chest x-ray can provide an overview of the thoracic cavity, including the lungs, heart, and major thoracic vessels. However, it may not show the detailed anatomy required to diagnose dysphagia lusoria, which involves the compression of the esophagus by an aberrant vessel.

 

Option B. Electrocardiogram (ECG): An ECG records the electrical activity of the heart and cannot visualize structural anomalies of the esophagus or great vessels.

 

Option C. Echocardiogram: An echocardiogram can detect congenital heart anomalies; it is not the first choice for visualizing extracardiac structures like the esophagus or aberrant arteries causing dysphagia lusoria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Computed tomography angiography is the imaging modality of choice to diagnose dysphagia lusoria, as it can confirm the presence of an aberrant right subclavian artery causing compression of the esophagus.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 210.

choices.text: Kerley B lines
Cardiomegaly
Interlobular septal thickening
Pulmonary Oligemia

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in heart failure?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pulmonary Oligemia

 

Option D:

 

Pulmonary oligemia denotes a decrease in the pulmonary vascular markings and is indicative of reduced blood flow or volume in the pulmonary vasculature. This is not characteristic of heart failure, where typically there is pulmonary congestion and not a reduction in blood flow to the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Kerley B lines: Kerley B lines are horizontal opaque lines extending to the pulmonary periphery associated with interstitial pulmonary edema. They are often seen in heart failure due to elevated pulmonary venous pressure causing fluid to accumulate within the interlobular septa.

 

Option B. Cardiomegaly: Cardiomegaly can be caused by dilatation of the heart chambers or hypertrophy of the heart muscle in response to increased workload from heart failure.

 

Option C. Interlobular Septal Thickening: Interlobular septal thickening is seen on chest imaging when there is fluid or fibrosis in the interlobular septa, which are part of the lung's supportive tissue. This is another manifestation of interstitial edema commonly observed in heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary oligemia, which refers to decreased lung vascular markings due to reduced pulmonary blood flow, is not observed in heart failure. Instead, heart failure is characterized by findings like Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly, and interlobular septal thickening due to fluid accumulation and increased pressures in the pulmonary circulation.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 166.

choices.text: Descending aorta
Superior vena cava
Ascending aorta
Right pulmonary artery

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the CT scan shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior vena cava

 

Option B:

 

The structure marked as 'A' in the CT thorax is the superior vena cava.

 

Superior Vena Cava The SVC is located in the anterior right superior mediastinum, which is consistent with the location of the structure marked in the image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Descending Aorta: The descending aorta typically lies posteriorly in the mediastinum and would not be located in the position marked in the provided CT image.

 

Option C. Ascending Aorta: The ascending aorta would generally be seen slightly leftward in the mediastinal space in a CT scan. It should appear as a prominent, rounded structure due to the flow of contrast within it.

 

Option D. Right Pulmonary Artery: The right pulmonary artery on CT scan, is usually located anterior to the descending aorta and to the left of the ascending aorta and SVC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 216

choices.text: Pericardial friction rub
Dull note on right lower chest
Ellis S curve
Hyper-resonant note on right lower chest

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease presents to the emergency room with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, but he appears to be in respiratory distress. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternAns. CXR was performed which is shown here. What is the likely finding on auscultation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pericardial friction rub

 

Option A:

 

The cardiac shadow is enlarged suggestive of money bag appearance in the provided image and is typically seen in pericardial effusion. A friction rub is caused by the inflamed layers of the pericardium rubbing against each other during cardiac contraction and relaxation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Dull note on right lower chest: Pleural effusion, which is an accumulation of fluid in the pleural space. The dullness on percussion is due to the fluid present in the pleural space.

 

Option C. Ellis S curve: Rising note of dullness laterally in pleural effusion

 

Option D. Hyper-resonant note on right lower chest: Pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space. The hyper-resonance on percussion is due to the increased amount of air present in the pleural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest X-ray, indicative of a "water bottle" or "money bag" appearance, along with ECG evidence of low voltage QRS complexes and electrical alternans, the likely auscultatory finding is a pericardial friction rub, which is associated with pericardial effusion and pericarditis.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 36

choices.text: Straightening of right cardiac border
Enlargement of left atrial appendage
Presence of double atrial shadow
Elevation of left main bronchus and widening of carina

questions.text: What is the earliest sign of left atrial enlargement on a chest x-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Enlargement of left atrial appendage

 

Option B:

 

The early indication of left atrial enlargement (LAE) on a chest x-ray is an expansion of the left atrial appendage, resulting in a fullness perceived underneath the pulmonary artery. This leads to a straightening of the left heart border, as the left atrium is the only structure contributing to this border.

 

Enlargement of Left Atrial Appendage The enlargement of the left atrial appendage is one of the earliest signs of left atrial enlargement (LAE) on a chest X-ray. It presents as fullness beneath the pulmonary artery segment, causing obliteration of the concavity normally seen at this location, resulting in a straight left heart border.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Straightening of the Right Cardiac Border: Straightening of the right cardiac border is associated with right atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. Presence of Double Atrial Shadow: The presence of a double atrial shadow, also known as the "double density sign," occurs when the enlarged left atrium projects over the right heart border on the posteroanterior (PA) chest X-ray.

 

Option D. Elevation of Left Main Bronchus and Widening of Carina: Elevation of the left main bronchus and widening of the carina angle can be a consequence of LAE, as the enlarged left atrium may push the left bronchus superiorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The earliest radiographic sign of left atrial enlargement on a chest X-ray is the enlargement of the left atrial appendage, leading to obliteration of the concavity beneath the pulmonary artery and a straightened left heart border.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 166

choices.text: Egg in cup sign
Egg on string sign
Money bag appearance
Box shaped heart

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought by her mother to her primary care physician with a history of chronic shortness of breath and fatigue. She reports that her symptoms have been progressively worsening over the past year, and she is no longer able to perform her usual activities of daily living without experiencing significant dyspnea. On physical examination, the physician notes a prominent jugular venous pulse with a giant "a" wave and a soft systolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. An electrocardiogram shows right atrial enlargement, right ventricular hypertrophy, and right bundle branch block. An echocardiogram is ordered, which reveals a displaced tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, with severe tricuspid regurgitation and a small right ventricle. What is the likely appearance on CXR?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Box shaped heart

 

Option D:

 

 

The given scenario describes a typical case of Ebstein anomaly. The CXR depicts an enlarged, box-shaped cardiac silhouette, that is characteristically seen in Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Egg in cup sign: Calcific pericarditis typically appears as a dense, curvilinear, or band-like opacity that surrounds the heart, often described as a "shaggy heart" appearance. The calcification can also extend into the adjacent mediastinal fat, creating a dense, well-defined line that separates the heart from the lungs.

 

Option B. Egg on side: This is a radiological sign seen in TGA. Transposition of the Great Arteries, which is a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary artery and aorta, are switched (or "transposed") in position. This means that the aorta arises from the right ventricle, and the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle.

 

Option C. Money bag sign is typically seen in pericardial effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Ebstein anomaly, the chest X-ray typically reveals a box-shaped heart due to atrialization of the right ventricle and enlargement of the heart's silhouette.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 150

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect
TAPVC
Atrial septal defect
Tetralogy of Fallot

questions.text: A 10-year-old child who presents with shortness of breath and difficulty exercising. On examination, a fixed, split-second heart sound is heard, and there is a palpable thrill felt on the chest. Hilar dance was seen on fluoroscopy. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Atrial septal defect

 

Option C:

 

Fluoroscopy reveals a Hilar dance in patients with an atrial septal defect (ASD). It is caused by rapid pulmonary artery pulsations.

 

ASD presents with a fixed, split-second heart sound because the septal defect results in increased blood flow through the right heart, leading to prolonged right ventricular systole and a fixed splitting of S2. The palpable thrill could be due to increased flow across the pulmonary artery, and hilar dance can be seen on fluoroscopy due to increased pulmonary artery pulsations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): A VSD typically presents with a harsh-sounding holosystolic murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border. A thrill may be palpable, but a fixed, split-second heart sound is not characteristic of VSD. Hilar dance on fluoroscopy is not a common finding associated with VSD.

 

Option B. Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC): TAPVC is a congenital defect where the pulmonary veins do not connect normally to the left atrium. Instead, they are connected to the systemic venous circulation. It is often associated with signs of heart failure and cyanosis but not typically with a fixed, split-second heart sound or hilar dance.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF): TOF commonly presents with cyanotic episodes, especially during crying or feeding, and a harsh systolic murmur due to pulmonary stenosis. A fixed, split-second heart sound is not typical in TOF, nor is hilar dance on fluoroscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The child's clinical presentation, including a fixed, split-second heart sound and hilar dance on fluoroscopy, suggests increased pulmonary blood flow, consistent with an atrial septal defect.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 160

choices.text: Persistent truncus arteriosus
Transposition of great vessels
Tetralogy of Fallot
Pulmonary artery hypertension

questions.text: A newborn baby who presents with cyanosis of the skin and mucous membranes. The baby also has difficulty feeding, with labored breathing. Chest X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Persistent truncus arteriosus

 

Option A:

 

Persistent truncus arteriosus is a cyanotic congenital heart anomaly in which a single trunk supplies both the pulmonary and systemic circulation and on chest X-ray it is characterized by the sitting duck appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Transposition of great vessels on a chest X-ray shows Egg on string sign.

 

Option C. Tetralogy of Fallot characteristically shows boot shaped heart

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertension clearly enlarged pulmonary arteries with pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent truncus arteriosus is a cyanotic congenital heart anomaly where a single vessel arises from the heart, supplying both the systemic and pulmonary circulations, often associated with a characteristic "sitting duck" appearance on a chest X-ray.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 154

choices.text: TAPVC
Tricuspid atresia
Ebstein’s anomaly
TOF

questions.text: Plethoric lung fields are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. TAPVC

 

Option A:

 

Plethoric lung fields are indicative of increased pulmonary arterial blood flow and are seen in:

 

left to right shunts

TAPVC

TGA

Persistent truncus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tricuspid atresia does not have plethoric lung fields because in this condition right atrium is atretic.

 

Option C. Ebstein’s anomaly has atrialization of RV, leading to small outflow tract, and resultant reduced pulmonary blood flow.

 

Option D. TOF has oligemia due to infundibular pulmonary stenosis. 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 152.

choices.text: Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus
Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC
Egg on side, TGA
Boot shaped heart, TOF

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Option B:

 

The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance.

 

Snowman Sign, Supracardiac TAPVC: Supracardiac Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC) is where the pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium, or a systemic vein, rather than the left atrium. The "snowman" or "figure of 8" sign on a chest X-ray is characterized by a supracardiac shadow, representing the dilated vertical vein, and the heart, creating a snowman-like image.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cottage Loaf, Truncus Arteriosus: In persistent truncus arteriosus, a single arterial trunk comes out of the heart, supplying both the pulmonary and systemic circulation. The chest X-ray might show a "cottage loaf" or "boot-shaped" heart due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and overriding aorta.

 

Option C. Egg on Side, TGA: Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA) presents with cyanosis early after birth and on a chest X-ray shows the "egg on a string" sign. This sign is characterized by a narrow mediastinal silhouette with an enlarged cardiac silhouette, which resembles an egg on its side. The "string" part is due to the narrow superior mediastinum, often seen in TGA.

 

Option D. Boot Shaped Heart, TOF: The chest X-ray in TOF can show a "boot-shaped" heart due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upturned apex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chest X-ray demonstrating a "snowman" sign indicates a diagnosis of Supracardiac TAPVC, a condition where the pulmonary veins drain into the systemic circulation rather than the left atrium, commonly presenting with cyanosis and symptoms of heart failure in infancy.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 152

choices.text: Coarctation of aorta
Essential hypertension
Hyperparathyroidism
Takayasu arteritis

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented with hypertension and chest pain. A chest radiograph was taken as shown in the image below. What is the likely cause of hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Option A:

 

The given clinical scenario and the chest X-ray depicting the figure of 3 sign are suggestive of coarctation of aorta to be the cause of hypertension in this patient.

 

Typical C/F: Brachio-femoral delay – upper limb pulsations/BP is high; Lower limb pulsation /BP is feeble

Figure of 3 sign on CXR

Inferior rib notching – Roesler's sign

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Essential Hypertension: It typically does not produce specific changes on a chest radiograph.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: It does not create specific signs on a chest radiograph related to the aorta.

 

Option D. Takayasu Arteritis: While it can cause hypertension due to renal artery involvement, it would also typically show thickening or narrowing of the aorta or its branches on imaging, not the "figure of 3" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "figure of 3" sign on a chest radiograph, coupled with a clinical presentation of hypertension and chest pain in a young adult, is indicative of coarctation of the aorta, a congenital condition that can cause secondary hypertension due to the narrowing of the aorta.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 156

choices.text: Pulmonary embolism
Pulmonary hypertension
Pulmonary edema
Pulmonary infarction

questions.text:
A 36-year-old male presents with progressive shortness of breath and fatigue, particularly with physical activity. A loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound is heard on examination. The patient also notices swelling and tightness of the skin in the fingers, hands, and face, joint pain and stiffness, and difficulty swallowing.

CXR is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hypertension

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of a case of scleroderma with PAH, likely secondary to ILD. Peripheral pruning is the tapering of the peripheral arterial branches which a characteristic radiologic feature of Pulmonary artery hypertension.

 

Pulmonary Hypertension: Symptoms of progressive shortness of breath, fatigue, and signs like a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound are suggestive of pulmonary hypertension. The CXR may show enlarged pulmonary arteries and pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels. Scleroderma, mentioned as part of the clinical syndrome, is associated with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism usually presents acutely with chest pain, dyspnea, and hypoxia. The CXR may show a Westermark sign or a Hampton's hump.

 

Option C. Pulmonary Edema: Pulmonary edema presents with acute onset dyspnea, orthopnea, and pink frothy sputum, often with Kerley B lines, peribronchial cuffing, and "bat's wing" appearance on CXR.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Infarction A pulmonary infarction is a rare sequelae of a pulmonary embolism and can present with pleuritic chest pain and hemoptysis. On CXR, you may see a peripheral wedge-shaped infiltrate, which is not evident here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The constellation of symptoms including progressive dyspnea, skin changes suggestive of scleroderma, and CXR findings indicative of right heart strain strongly suggest pulmonary hypertension as the diagnosis.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 186

choices.text: Pulmonary embolism
Aortic dissection
Aortic aneurysm
Myocardial infarction

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has come with sudden onset of chest pain and his CT scan shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic dissection

 

Option B:

 

Aortic dissection is suggested by the CT scan, which shows a double lumen and aortic dilatation of descending aorta.

 

IOC (for stable patients) →CTA (CT angiography)

 

IOC for unstable patients → TEE (Transesophageal echocardiography)

 

Aortic dissection is characterized by an intimal tear, leading to the creation of a false lumen as blood splits the layers of the aortic wall. On a CT scan, this appears as a double lumen with an intimal flap. It is commonly associated with hypertension and connective tissue disorders.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism is typically indicated on CT scans by a filling defect within the pulmonary arteries. Risk factors include deep vein thrombosis, immobilization, and hypercoagulable states.

 

Option C. Aortic Aneurysm: Aortic aneurysms are localized dilatations of the aorta and would show as a single widened aorta without the presence of an intimal flap or double lumen on a CT scan.

 

Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Myocardial infarction, or a heart attack, involves the necrosis of heart muscle due to ischemia. It is diagnosed primarily through ECG changes and blood tests showing elevated cardiac enzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CT angiography characteristic of aortic dissection is the visualization of an intimal flap and the formation of a false lumen within the aorta.

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 194

choices.text: Radiate from the hilum of lungs
Runs perpendicular to the pleural surface
Are oblique lines
Seen in ARDS

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Kerley B lines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B: Runs perpendicular to the pleural surface

 

Explanation:

 

Kerley lines are seen when the interlobular septa in the pulmonary interstitium become prominent due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

 

Types of Kerley lines:

 

Kerley A lines:

 

oblique lines towards the hila

 

Extend radially from the hilum to the upper lobes.

 

Kerley B lines:

 

At the base of the lung.

 

Run perpendicular to the pleural surface

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 116.

choices.text: Widening of the mediastinum
Pulmonary infiltrates
Bilateral pleural effusions
Hyperinflation of the lungs

questions.text: Which of the following radiographic findings is most commonly seen in aortic dissection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Widening of the mediastinum

 

Option A:

 

The most classic radiographic sign of aortic dissection on a chest X-ray is mediastinal widening. It indicates the presence of a hematoma within the mediastinum due to the dissection of the aorta.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pulmonary Infiltrates: Pulmonary infiltrates on a chest X-ray would appear as areas of increased opacity within the lung parenchyma. They are more commonly associated with pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or inflammatory conditions, not typically with aortic dissection.

 

Option C. Bilateral Pleural Effusions: Bilateral pleural effusions would present as blunting of the costophrenic angles and fluid in the pleural space.

 

Option D. Hyperinflation of the Lungs: Hyperinflation is characterized by increased lung volumes and is commonly seen in obstructive lung diseases like asthma or COPD. It is characterized by a flattening of the diaphragm on chest X-ray .

 

Educational Objective:

 

Widening of the mediastinum is the most common radiographic finding associated with aortic dissection, seen on a chest X-ray as an increased mediastinal silhouette. This is indicative of the presence of a hematoma due to blood flow between the layers of the aortic wall.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 194.

choices.text: Pulmonary embolism
Pulmonary edema
Pneumoconiosis
Sarcoidosis

questions.text: The following CXR appearance is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary edema

 

Option B:

 

Batwing appearance refers to a radiographic pattern in which there is diffuse opacity in the central part of the lung fields with relative sparing of the peripheral areas. This pattern resembles the shape of bat wings, hence the name.

 

Batwing appearance is a characteristic finding in pulmonary edema, which is a condition in which excess fluid accumulates in the lungs due to various reasons such as heart failure, kidney failure, or acute respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulmonary embolism typically presents with focal areas of opacity on chest radiographs known as Hampton’s hump.

 

Option C. Pneumoconiosis is a lung disease caused by inhalation of dust particles and typically presents with nodular opacities on chest radiographs predominantly in upper lobe.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease that can affect multiple organs including the lungs, and typically presents with hilar lymphadenopathy and nodular opacities on chest radiographs, predominantly in upper lobe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "batwing" appearance on a chest X-ray is indicative of pulmonary edema, typically resulting from conditions such as heart failure, which leads to excess fluid accumulation in the alveolar and interstitial spaces of the lungs.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 116.
